verse: From the blue, purple, and scarlet material, they made finely woven garments for ministering in the Holy Place, and they made the holy garments for Aaron, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
He made the special vest from gold and from blue, purple, and scarlet material and fine woven linen.
They beat the gold into thin sheets and cut it into threads so that they could work it into the blue, purple, and scarlet material and into the fine linen, the work of a skilled craftsman.
They made two shoulder straps for the top, one on each side, so that the vest could be fastened together.
The decorated sash, which is attached to the vest, was made just like it: of gold, of blue, purple, and scarlet material, and of fine woven linen, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
They took two onyx stones and mounted them in gold settings and engraved on them the names of the sons of Israel, like the engraving on signet seals.
They mounted them on the shoulder straps of the vest as memorial stones for the sons of Israel, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
Bezalel made a folded pouch, the work of a skillful craftsman. He made it with the same workmanship as the vest. He made it of gold, and of blue, purple, and scarlet material and of fine woven linen.
It was square, nine inches by nine inches when it was folded double.
They mounted on it four rows of precious stones. The first row was carnelian, diamond, and jacinth;
the second row agate, sapphire, and emerald;
the third row beryl, jasper, and ruby;
and the fourth row topaz, onyx, and turquoise. The stones were mounted in gold settings.
There were twelve stones, corresponding to the names of the sons of Israel. Each one was like an engraved seal with the name of one of the twelve tribes.
They made braided chains of pure gold for the pouch.
They made two gold rings for the pouch and attached the two rings to the top corners of the pouch.
They put the two braided gold chains into the two rings at the top corners of the pouch.
The other ends of the two braided chains they attached to the two settings, and then attached them to the shoulder straps on the front of the vest.
They made two gold rings and put them on the two lower corners of the pouch, on its inside edge, which is toward the vest.
They made two more gold rings and attached them to the two shoulder straps of the vest in the front, close to the bottom where it is joined to the sash of the vest.

They tied the rings of the pouch to the rings of the vest with a blue cord, so that the pouch was kept right next to the woven sash of the vest and would not swing out from the vest—just as the Lord had commanded Moses.

header: The Robe Worn With the Vest

verse: The robe that was to be worn under the vest was the work of a weaver. It was all blue.
It had an opening in the middle of its top for the head. It had a woven binding around the opening, like the opening of a collar, to prevent it from tearing.
For its hem they made pomegranates of blue, purple, and scarlet material.
They put the pomegranates around its hem with gold bells alternating with them
(a gold bell, then a pomegranate, a gold bell, then a pomegranate), all around the hem of the robe that was worn when ministering, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
They wove the tunics of fine linen, the work of a weaver, for Aaron and for his sons.
They made the turban and the small pointed turbans of fine linen, and the underwear was made from a special kind of finely woven linen.
The sash was made of finely woven linen, and blue, and purple, and scarlet material, the work of an embroiderer, just as the Lord commanded Moses.
They made a medallion of pure gold to serve as a crest and engraved on it (like the engravings on a seal): Holy to the Lord.
They put it on a blue cord to fasten it to the turban on the front, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
In this way all the work on the Dwelling, that is, the Tent of Meeting, was finished. The people of Israel did everything exactly as the Lord had commanded Moses.
They brought the Dwelling to Moses: the tent with all its furniture, its clasps, its boards, its crossbars, its posts, its socket bases,
the covering of rams’ skins dyed red, the covering made from hides of sea cows, the special veil,
the Ark of the Testimony with its poles, the atonement seat,
the table, all its utensils, the Bread of the Presence,
the pure gold lampstand, its lamps (that is, the lamps to be set out in order), all its vessels and utensils, the oil for the Light,
the golden altar, the anointing oil, the fragrant incense, the screen for the door of the Tent,
the bronze altar, its bronze grate, its poles, all of its utensils, the basin and its pedestal,

the hangings of the courtyard, its posts, its sockets, the screen for the gate of the courtyard, its ropes, its stakes, all the equipment for the service of the Dwelling (that is, the Tent of Meeting),
the finely woven garments for ministering in the Holy Place, the holy garments for Aaron the priest, and the garments for his sons to minister in the priest’s office.
So the people of Israel did all the work according to everything that the Lord had commanded Moses.
Moses inspected all the work, and he saw that they had done it exactly as the Lord had commanded, so Moses blessed them.
